article.headline: Connecticut 101, Ball State 62
article.story: HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) -- The inside-outside combination of Emeka Okafor and Ben Gordon led top-ranked Connecticut to its sixth straight win. The Huskies' smothering defense also helped. Okafor and Gordon scored 25 points and UConn limited Ball State to 35 percent shooting in a 101-62 victory Sunday. UConn (9-1) has held its last four opponents to an average of 30 percent shooting. "We always knew we had a lot of offensive weapons, but the thing we worry about most is defense," Gordon said. "We definitely want that to be our identify. We don't want to be just a team with a lot of good offensive players and can't lock people up." Okafor also had 14 boards for his sixth double-double of the season and the 34th in his three years with the Huskies. He also had five of UConn's 12 blocks. The Huskies got the Cardinals off their deliberate offensive style and turned up the tempo. In the end, Ball State was unable to run down the Huskies. Gordon often finished off the break, thrilling the crowd with flashy dunks. His roundhouse slam gave UConn a 66-37 lead and brought a deafening ovation. "They are relentless with how they attack you and they never give up with where they want to get the basketball," Ball State coach Tim Buckley said. Denham Brown added 20 points for the Huskies. Taliek Brown led UConn with eight assists and has 23 assists and just three turnover the last three games. Cameron Echols scored 22 points for the Cardinals (3-5), whose losing streak reached four games. Dennis Trammell and Robert Owens each scored 10 for Ball State. Okafor dominated the inside early, registering five blocks and 10 rebounds in the first 20 minutes. His six defensive rebounds in the first half fueled UConn's breakaway game. "We got the tempo of the game exactly where we wanted to," UConn coach Jim Calhoun said. "Anybody in the country wants to run with us, we're more than happy to run with them." Gordon had 13 points in the first half as the Huskies built a 41-23 lead at the break. UConn turned up its pressure and offense in the second half, converting two straight Ball State turnovers into four points in the first 12 seconds, and the Cardinals never recovered. The Huskies blew the game open, hitting their first 11 baskets in the second half. The Huskies shot 74 percent in the second half, scoring on easy inside baskets. UConn, led by Okafor, outscored the Cardinals 56 to 30 in the paint, and finished with a 49-33 rebounding edge. The Huskies remain unbeaten in eight games at home. UConn's only loss came against No. 4 Georgia Tech in the semifinals of the Preseason NIT. Okafor was hampered by back pain in the game. Since the setback, he's gotten healthy and Connecticut has won six straight. "Emeka is just a total physical mismatch for everybody he's played against thus far," Calhoun said, noting the exception was the 77-61 loss to the Yellow Jackets. The Huskies have stretched out the early part of the schedule, playing the last three games in 22 days. The pace will start to pick up with three games over the next six days starting with Massachusetts at home on Tuesday, then road games at Rice and Rutgers. "I think we are starting to truly believe we can do," Okafor said. "It's going to be a difficult road ... but it's going to be a lot of fun."
